docs.lead_paragraph: In building a bridge from welfare to work, Wisconsin, perhaps more than any other state, has prided itself on doing things right. It has spent heavily and pledged lavishly to give poor families the tools they need, from baby sitters and bus passes to case managers and community service jobs. On paper, no state has done more to replace welfare checks with workers' supports. But a year after moving from the shelves to the streets, Wisconsin's celebrated effort bears only an intermittent likeness to the program of customized employment services outlined in planning documents and praised from the Oval Office on down. In practice, even supporters of the program complain that uneven casework and unresponsive bureaucracies can make services cumbersome, if not impossible, to use.

headline.main: Wisconsin Welfare Experiment: Easy to Say, Not So Easy to Do

docs.abstract: Wisconsin's widely hailed year-old effort to help Milwaukee's poor move from welfare to work is plagued in practice by uneven casework and unresponsive bureaucracies that can make customized employment services cumbersome, if not impossible, to use; gaps between generous theory and bumpy practice are noteworthy because Wisconsin plan has helped shape national consensus on aid to poor; many former welfare recipients have achieved kind of back-door success by walking away from program to find jobs on own; graph of drop in welfare cases in state; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 NATO Warning to Milosevic On Kosovo Withdrawal NATO told President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia that he has until tomorrow to reduce his forces in Kosovo or face a renewed threat of air strikes, though it looked increasingly unlikely that such a threat will be carried out.
